Joyce N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Joyce has a small restaurant that sells cooked food, which she has had for less than one year.  She also has a second business selling soft drinks  

To help expand her business, Joyce has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food and chairs for the restaurant.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Joyce hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees for her child.  In the future, Joyce hopes to own a salon.

Joyce is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning more tactics on how to make money from her business.

loans.use: to purchase more food and chairs for her little restaurant.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng P. is a 29-year-old married woman and a local villager living in Baray district, Kompong Tom province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops: rice and vegetables. Her husband works as a construction worker.

 Seng P. is blessed with a child who is attending local school. Seng P. is looking for a loan as capital to support her farming business. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed for planting.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seed for planting.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 28 years old. She is married and has three children. The oldest is seven and the youngest is one year old. The older two go to school. Her husband is a technician. 

Currently, she sells food in a restaurant. It's now four years since she opened the restaurant. She rents a house in which she does her restaurant business. She will use the loan to buy rice, sugar, beans and milk. With the profits she will pay school fees for her children and together with her savings buy a small house. She is hoping to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy food for her restaurant.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet L. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Annet has a poultry farm, which she has had for two years.  She also has a second business: outdoor catering.  

To help expand her businesses, Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more chicken feed.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Annet hopes to build rental houses.  

Annet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her to learn how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more chicken feed for her poultry business.

loans.name: Ofelya

texts.en:
Ofelya E. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Tufashen.  She has a strong connection with her homeland and has been an honest, hard-working farmer for the past twenty years.  Ofelya’s agriculture activities support her family and her sisters who live in the city.  

As a single entrepreneur she hopes to grow her business and continue to support her family.  She is looking for a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer. 

 According to Ofelya’s plans, the investment will substantially increase her income.  She likes the convenience of microfinance services, and the prices are reasonable.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
Ariel A. is from the village of Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. He is 43 years old. Ariel is married and has eight school-aged children. To earn an income for his family needs, he engages in a transportation business operating a motorcycle. Being in the business for 5 years, Ariel already has many customers thus making him earn at least 4000 PHP a month. 

In 2007, Ariel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ariel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair his existing vehicle for better service. Ariel is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Ariel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 49 years old, married and has two children. For the last three years, she has made a living by running a school and earns a monthly income of KES. 5,000. She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD to renovate her classrooms and buy more desks for her students. In the future, she hopes to expand her school and earn enough money to build a home in which her family can live.

loans.use: to renovate classrooms and buy more desks.

loans.name: Nidy

texts.en:
Nidy lives in the village of Ciriaco Pastrano, Oroquieta City. She is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. For the last five years, she has made a living by running a retail store where she earns about 3,000 PHP a month. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC and is applying for a new one, for 14,000 PHP, to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to continue improving and expanding her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet M. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Juliet has a business selling milk, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more milk for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Juliet hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food.  In the future, Juliet hopes to expand her business. 

Juliet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her more on how to use money wisely.

loans.use: to purchase more milk for resale.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 29 years old and married with five children between 14 and 4 years old. He resides in his native town of Kitale, Western Kenya with his family and does farming. He produces and sells milk and vegetables to the local market.

Peter has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this loan will enable him to improve his family's living standards through the availability of milk for the family consumption and resale. He would like to acquire four dairy cows and become the main milk seller in the area.

Peter is focusing on repaying this second loan so he can acquire more loans.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more items to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 23 years old and single. He sometimes takes temporary jobs such as washing clothes, cleaning a compound, etc. to earn a living. He has been working this way for 5 years. He also sells phone accessories and kitchen utensils. 

With the loan, he will buy more phone accessories, kitchen foil, etc. to sale. He hopes to buy a house with the profits that he hopes to make.

loans.use: To buy phone accessories and kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Kanyansheko Bakyara Twimukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
B. Vincent is the leader of Kanyansheko bakyara group in Ibanda. He is 42 years old, married, and has 4 children. He has a salon business where he works on ladies' and men’s hair. He also sells hair oils and chemicals. He employs one person and he is able to make 70,000 as weekly profits. 

Vincent is also involved in the sale of matooke (green fruit of the banana family, prepared by steaming), mostly from his plantations. He does buy some matooke from other farmers. He has had this business for 5 years and he started it with a loan. He is so happy that the business worked for him the first time. He needs a loan to be able to modernize his business by buying more furniture and oils for his customers.

loans.use: to buy more furniture and oil for his customers.

loans.name: Hovhannes

texts.en:
Hovhannes G. is from the village of Akhouryan in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is happily married and, together with his wife, has been working on the family farm for the past ten years. He hopes to save enough money someday to renovate the family home. In addition to providing for his family, Hovhannes also helps his brother’s family with produce grown on the family farm.  

Hovhannes would like a loan to purchase animal feed. He expects the family income to increase by twenty five percent with this investment. He enjoys living in Akhuryan and is surrounded by his relatives and good friends.

loans.use: to buy animal feed.

loans.name: Siddiqan's Group

texts.en:
Siddiqan is a resident of Jaranawala which is located in Punjab province of Pakistan. She has been living there with her family for the past 25 years. Her husband's name is A. L. and he operates a donkey cart with which he provides loading/unloading services to his clients. He has a good reputation among his clients due to timely delivery of the products to the designated places. 

Siddiqan herself is a housewife as well as a working woman. Besides her household work, she operates a dairy business at her home. She keeps three buffaloes and 2 goats at her home. She takes care of them and sells their milk to her community clients.  She is a mother of seven children. Her eldest son has a construction supplies business while her elder daughter weaves carpets. She is very skillful and weaves beautiful carpets which sell in a very good price range.  

Siddiqan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in improving his loading business. Using the loan, he will buy a new cart that will help him put more loads on his cart and provide better services to his customers. Basically, his old cart has become rough and doesn’t carry heavy loads. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Siddiqan is hopeful that her husband will make full use of loan money and improve his business. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her family.
 
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Siddiqan.

loans.use: To buy a new cart for loading/unloading business.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline B. is from the village of Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. She is 57 years old. Evangeline is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 33000 PHP which will be used to purchase stock of products such as soap, condiments, canned goods and soft drinks. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Evangeline from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase inventory of products such as soap, condiments, canned goods and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a boat to pick up passengers.

loans.name: Muhumure

texts.en:
Muhumure S. is an individual client from Ibanda. He is 35 years old, married, and has 4 children. Three of his children are already in school. S. has had a bar business in Bugorobi trading centre for 5 years and he sells mostly sodas, beers, wines, spirits, water and so on. His customers are mostly the surrounding community. He is able to generate 700,000 UGX weekly. In addition, he also sells produce, films with DSTV and bananas from his farm. He owns a boda boda (bicycle taxi) that he hires out for extra income. 

S. is committed to succeed. He is business-oriented and his dream is to be able to own a big bar, to own lodging facilities and to educate his children. S. is a new client and he hopes to improve his business with the loan by buying more inventory for the bar.

loans.use: To buy more liquor and soft drinks for the bar.

loans.name: Toch

texts.en:
Toch K., 55, resides in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known as one of Angkorean Temples. K. is a housewife. Her husband is a security guard, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 25 on food and USD 60 on other necessary expenses. 

K. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a tuk-tuk (motorized three-wheeled rickshaw) for one of her children to start a new business as a tuk-tuk driver. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a tuk tuk for the children to start a new business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is from the village of Mobod, Oroquieta City. She is 49 years old, married and has two grown children. To make a living, Mercy runs a snack-vending business in the local community. 

Mercy has been engaged in her business for 10 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC.

Mercy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, with which she will purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business. This will be the second loan taken out by Mercy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

loans.name: Pin

texts.en: Pin K., aged 32, is a married woman who lives in Kopong Tom province. She is a domestic rice seller in Tang Krosang market. She also buys rice in bulk at a reasonable cost to mill, and she sells her finished rice to people to earn extra income. Her husband is a fisherman as well as a construction worker. Usually Pin K. generates around $2.5 USD of profit per day to meet the needs of her family. She needs capital to purchase many sacks of rice to store. She will sell them when rice is commanding the highest price.

loans.use: to stock up on rice when the price is low for future resale.

loans.name: Hayastan

texts.en:
Hayastan H. is from the village of Arpeni in the Shirak region of Armenia. Even though Hayastan has a university degree as a foreign language teacher; the economic difficulties in the Shirak region have not permitted Hayastan to find a teaching job. In order to provide for her family Hayastan has been a hard working farmer for the past thirty years.  

Hayastan and her husband work on the family farm. They have three children – a twenty-four year old daughter and two sons (thirty-three and thirty-four).  She dreams of having her daughter complete her education, to be able to work and have a family. Hayastan would like a loan to purchase livestock and feed. According to her business plan this investment will increase the family income by thirty percent. Hayastan is pleased with the services of microfinance and looks forward to expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and animal feed.

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel, a 34-year-old married mother of three children aged 11, 9 and 7, started her business five years ago, having bought land upon which to grow rice. Richel earns approximately 5000 PHP from this enterprise, and she also makes native products such as baskets to sell at the market.

Now in need of farm inputs, she is requesting a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers. Richel is hopeful this loan will help to improve her harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Dul

texts.en:
Dul N., 42, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known as one of Pre-Angkorean Temples. N. sells bananas, earning an income of USD 10 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 35 on food and USD 60 on other necessary expenses. 

N. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a tuk-tuk (three-wheeled motorized rickshaw) for one of her children to start a new business as a tuk-tuk driver. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a tuk-tuk for the children to start a new business.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine is 37 years old .She is married. Her one child, who is 8 years old, goes to school.

Clementine sells soft drinks to earn a living. She has done this business for 12 years and it has enabled her to pay her house rent easily with no difficulties. She is requesting a loan to buy more soft drinks and, hence, to make more profits. With the profits, she plans to pay her child’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks.

loans.name: Shokir

texts.en:
Shokir lives in Tursunzade, Tajikistan and he has three children. He has a truck and provides the services of transportation of sand, stones and gravel. Having attended to this business for 2 years, he has gained valuable experience. The business is stable and generates the main considerable income for Shokir’s family, allowing improved living conditions. Currently, Shokir wants to expand his business. For this purpose, he needs to take a loan of 1500$ USD. He intends to purchase spare parts for the repairing of his truck. Shokir thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan with accuracy.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy spare parts and to repair a truck.

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun S., 40, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known as one of Pre-Angkorean Temples. S. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 20 on food and USD 45 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase pigs to raise and resell. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy pigs to raise and resell.

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs.Oyuntsetseg is a 52 year old nurse. She works in a hospital. Her husband is a taxi driver and runs a taxi business, using the family car, bringing extra income for the family. They live with their two daughters and one grandson in ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

Mrs.Oyuntsetseg is applying for a loan to buy tires, two shock absorbers and some spare parts for the engine to service her family's car. Her husband uses this car as a taxi.

loans.use: To buy tires, two shock absorbers and some spare parts for the engine of the family's car, which her husband uses as a taxi.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy timber laundering machine wood workshop

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida belongs to Jaranwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house with her family for the past 25 years. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband. Her husband will utilize the loan money in buying milk in larger quantity for selling. His shop is located near his home and he makes good sales every month due to the good quality of milk he provides to his customers.  

He started this business two years ago and it is providing him regular profits. Zubaida is confident that an investment will give more profit to her husband because then he will be able to fulfill the demand of many other customers and make them his regular customers as well.  

Zubaida is a caring lady who carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and also supports her husband financially by weaving carpets. She learnt this skill from her mother and is now transferring this skill to her eldest daughter who is 18 years old and also works with her to complete the orders on time. 
 
Zubaida has given birth to three daughters and a son. Two of her children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she has proved herself as a responsible client by paying her installments on time and by attending every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Zubaida.

loans.use: To buy milk in larger quantity for selling.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn is 38 years old and is a married woman. She has 2 children aged 19 and 10.

Roselyn is a farmer working in Santo Niño, South Cotabato. She grows rice to sell. Roselyn also owns and manages a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells items like canned goods.

Roselyn is going to use her loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Nune

texts.en:
Nune H. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Gtashen. She is married and has three sons (nineteen, twenty-three and twenty-four years old). Nune has been farming the land for over twenty three years. She considers herself to be a honest hard-working person. In addition to providing for her family, Nune also provides relatives living in the city with produce grown on the family farm. 

She is pleased with microfinance services and is looking for a loan to purchase seeds, animal feed, fertilizer and fuel. She expects this investment to increase the family income by twenty percent. She dreams that her children will have happy and healthy lives. Nune enjoys the fresh air and the natural environment of the village of Gtashen.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, animal feed, fertilizer and fuel.

loans.name: Famille Yenawa Group

texts.fr:
FAMILLE YENAWA est un groupe constitué de trois personnes dont la présidente (dont le doigt est levé sur la photo) se nomme  Françoise Mekpondon. Les membres du groupe appartiennent à la même famille. Ce groupe sollicite un crédit en vue de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d'augmenter leur chiffre d'affaire.
Née le 20 février 1960 à Dangbo dans le département de l’Ouémé, Françoise Mekpondon vit depuis onze ans à Yénawa à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Françoise Mekpondon est mariée à Jean Bosco et à eu  trois  enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux à sa charge. Françoise Mekpondon vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. N’ayant pas été à l’école, Françoise Mekpondon vend depuis longtemps, des produits vivriers (sacs de maïs, de riz, carton de pâte...) à son domicile ; ce qui lui permet de se prendre en charge et de nourrir sa famille. Françoise Mekpondon s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Françoise Mekpondon sollicite un financement auprès de ALIDé, afin d'agrandir son activité et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire et son revenu. Françoise Mekpondon aimerait dans l’avenir ouvrir une boutique et rehausser davantage son activité.
texts.en:
FAMILLE YENAWA is a group which is comprised of three persons, including the president (with her finger raised in the photo) by the name of Françoise Mekpondon. The group members belong to the same family. This group is requesting a loan with the aim of raising their level of business and increasing her turnover. 

Born on February 20, 1960 in Dangbo in Ouémé County, Françoise Mekpondon has lived for eleven years in Yénawa, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Jean Bosco and had three children, who have all had schooling. Two of the children are in her care. Françoise Mekpondon lives together with her children and husband. 

Not having attended school, she has sold staple goods (sacks of corn and rice, boxes of pasta…) out of her house for a long time. This enables her to support herself and to feed her family. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. 

She is requesting financing from ALIDé in order to expand her business and to increase her turnover. For the future, she would like to open a shop and to boost her business further.

loans.use: to buy sacks of corn and rice and boxes of pasta and some sugar

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a purified drinking water business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy additional stocks of purified water to sell. Emma has been in this business for two years. She earns a further income from selling ready-to-wear clothing. Emma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of making some house improvements and of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of purified drinking water for resale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.en: Marie Claire is 34 years old. She is married to a builder. She has three children who are 3-6 years old. Marie owns a general store in which she sells sugar, soft drinks, rice and beans. She is requesting a loan to buy more items including soft drinks, rice, beans etc. With the profits she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks and some foodstuffs.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 50 years old and married with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Elizabeth has a ready to wear (RTW) clothing business in the Philippines. Elizabeth requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy RTW products to sell.

Elizabeth has been in this business for two years.  In the future, Elizabeth would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase RTW clothing to sell in her stall

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Felicisima

texts.en:
Felicisima is married with six children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Felicisima is 45 years old and two of her children are in school.

Felicisima has a ready to wear clothing (RTW) business in the Philippines. Felicisima requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy RTW products to sell.

Felicisima has been in this business for two years. In the future, Felicisima would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Juditha

texts.en:
Juditha is 45 years old and married with four children.

Juditha works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her store.

Juditha has borrowed and paid back 11 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for seven years and also earns an income from food vending.

Juditha aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en: Lorn S. is married to Mr. Sok Rith who has run a rice-planting business for some years in Kompong Cham province. On average, they make $3.25 USD of profit per day to meet the expenses of food, water and electricity, plus other necessary expenses. Lorn S. has four single children; most of them have jobs already, but one attends the public school. The walls of her house are getting old and really need repair, but she doesn’t have the funds to do them yet. Therefore, Lorn S. would like to request a Kiva loan to buy some poles to repair her broken walls.

loans.use: to buy some poles for repairing her broken walls.

loans.name: Hendriah

texts.en:
Hendriah is a resident farmer in Kitale Town in Western Kenya. She is 24 and married, with one three-year-old child. She has been in farming for four years, producing milk and vegetables and selling them in the local market. She gets additional income from a motorcycle transport business.

Hendriah has requested a loan of 61,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo for two purposes: 31,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow and the rest to buy poultry birds. She says the previous loans have improved her family's standard of living and she hopes this third loan will make their lives much better through having milk, some of which they will drink and some of which they will sell to pay for other family needs.

She is glad that Juhudi Kilimo is advancing these loans. She notes, however, that animal diseases are still a great challenge in the farming business.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and poultry birds.

loans.name: Ma. Chona

texts.en:
Ma. Chona is 43 years old and married, with two children. She works very hard to provide for them. Ma. Chona runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store.

Ma. Chona has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as bread, canned goods, and other miscellaneous items. In the future, she would like to repair and renovate her house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en:
Sophie Z. is 40 years old and married with 5 adult children. She manages a general store. She offers different products in their village at Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. She earns 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

Sophie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sophie is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items such as rice to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Sophie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as rice to expand product offering.

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette is 35 years old. She has 4 children. She is a hard working mother. Her husband is a driver. Jeannette is grateful that she makes good use of her profits. She owns and runs a small restaurant in which she sells cooked African dishes. Jeannette has been in this business for 1 year and 7 months and it has enabled her to meet her family's needs.

Jeannette is requesting a loan to purchase equipment for her restaurant. In the future, she plans to expand her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy restaurant equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cattle for resale.

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen lives in Jaranwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a 2-room brick house for almost seven years. Her husband is an animal seller and for this purpose he has some goats and sheep at home. He raises them and sells to butchers at a profit. He started this business a few years ago and it is earning him good profits regularly. 

Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. Using the loan, he will buy some goats and sheep for resale.
. 
Perveen is a mother of three sons. Two of them are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. She is hopeful that an investment will help her husband to expand his business and earn better profits.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she has proved herself a responsible client by paying her installments on time and by attending every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Perveen.

loans.use: To buy goats & sheep for resale.

loans.name: Fedrick Musembi

texts.en:
Fredrick has been practising crop-farming in Kavete village, in Tala town, for seven years. He earns an income of KES 1,500 per month. He is married to Nancy and they are blessed with three children. He sells his farm produce to the residents of Tala.

Fredrick learnt about KADET LTD through another group member. He is applying for his first loan of KES 15,000, which he plans to use in buying farm inputs like fertilizers and tomato seedlings.

In the future he plans to expand his business and to become a great farmer in the area.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs e.g fertilizers, tomato seeds.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. lives in the Mengo Mackay neighbourhood, in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 2 children, neither of whom are yet in school. Mary has a business of selling crafts. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Mary sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.    

Mary has requested  for a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use these funds to buy to buy more mats, baskets and hand woven caps. She also generates additional income through charcoal selling.

The main business challenge(s) for Mary include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesale seller and to start making crafts. Mary lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more mats, baskets and hand-woven caps.

loans.name: Merian

texts.en:
Merian G. is from the village of Songco, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 21 years old. Merian is married and has 1 child. To make a living, Merian owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages, shampoo, soap, sugars & instant noodles in the local community. Merian has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Merian joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Merian is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Merian from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods.

loans.name: Batsukh

texts.en:
Mr.Batsukh is 57 years old and a veterinarian. He has been working as a veterinarian for 31 years. His wife used to run a bakery shop making bread, but now she is planning to help with her husband’s business. 

Mr.Batsukh recently decided to run a veterinary business by opening a shop to treat animals and selling medicine for animals. He has already done some business planning and found a place to rent. Currently he is planning to do some proper restoration work on the building. The loan he is applying for will be used to buy necessary building materials and to do restoration work on the veterinarian shop.

loans.use: To buy necessary building materials and repair the veterinary shop which he is renting.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie is 47 years old and is a married woman with 4 children. Her oldest child is 21 years old.

Tessie is a farmer working in Santo Niño, South Cotabato. She grows rice crops to sell. Tessie earns just enough for her family. She hopes to earn better and be able to sustain her children's education.

Tessie plans to use her loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon T. Sr. is a 55-year-old fruit vendor from Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines.  He is happily married to Soledad T., his business partner.  They have been blessed with two children who have settled also with their own families.  At this time, Ramon and Soledad are working hand in hand to meet their daily needs.

Ramon has been into the buying and selling of tropical fruits for quite some time now. He buys these tropical fruits such as bananas and pineapples from farmers and wholesalers of their town in bulk quantities and sells them at a piece meal rate.  He also incorporates in his stall some vegetables and spices. Monthly, he earns an estimated net income of around 11,000 PHP.

To help him continue operation of his business, he is requesting a 8,000 PHP loan.  He plans to use this loan to buy more fresh fruit from wholesalers and also vegetables and spices to replenish his current inventory.  Ramon believes an increase in his business income will result as he expands his business.

Ramon prays for good health and be able to enjoy life with peace and abundance.  As a CCT community partner, he faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he reads.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional fresh fruit to sell.

loans.name: Larry

texts.en:
Larry S. is from the village of Babahagon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. He is 40 years old. Larry is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Larry owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap & instant noodles in the local community. Larry has been engaged in his business for over 16 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Larry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Larry is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages & snack foods. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Larry from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

He is requesting a loan to buy different kinds of foodstuffs and some restaurant equipment. He planes to renovate his house with the additional profits he hopes to make.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and poultry chicks.

loans.name: Yann

texts.en: Yann T. is a 56-year-old widow who livies in the Reussey Keo community of Phnom Penh City. To earn a living, she sells soup and meatballs at her house, earning an income of about $4 each day. She was widowed a few years ago, when her husband became ill and died. Now she lives with five kids, of whom two are single and three are married. She also relies on the income of her son, who is a building worker. Yann T. says she faces difficulties in travelling: when she needs to go out, she always hires a motor taxi. In order to solve the problem, Yann T. has requested a loan of $800, which she will use to buy a used motorcycle that she can use instead of hiring a taxi.

loans.use: to buy a used motorcycle to provide transportation need without hiring a taxi.

loans.name: Lorie

texts.en:
Lorie is from the village of Bolibol, Oroquieta City. She is 25 years old, married and has two infant children. To make a living, Lorie runs a general store. Her main source of income comes from selling food in the local community.

Lorie has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities. Lorie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. 

Lorie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP with which she will purchase a variety of products such as canned goods, shampoo, soap, etc. for her retail store. This will be the second loan taken out by Emily from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products such as canned goods, shampoo, soap, etc. for her retail store.

loans.name: Mathien

texts.en:
Mathien is 27 years old. He has one child who is three years old. His wife runs the same business as Mathien. Mathien owns a shop in which he sells a number of items such as sugar, Irish potatoes, beans, and both green and sweet bananas. They have been in this business for three years. This business has helped him meet his family needs and renovate his house as well. 

Mathien is requesting a loan to buy more items including foodstuffs and add to his shop inventory.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for resale.

loans.name: Johnny

texts.en:
Johnny C. is a 30-year-old, married man from the village of Songco, Lantapan, Bukidnon. Johnny and his wife have one school-age child. To earn a living, Johnny owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. Specifically, he runs a sari-sari (variety) shop, and his primary source of income is derived from buying and selling items like bread, junk food, canned goods, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in his local community. He also makes and sells barbecue meats (pork and chicken). Johnny has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2011, Johnny joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, he hopes to be better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve his family's standard of living. Johnny is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and junk food. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Johnny from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional canned goods and junk food

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan M. is 38-year old fruit vendor from Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. He is happily married to Maria Marilyn, his business partner. Allan is a college undergraduate and decided to run a micro-enterprise. Allan has been buying and selling tropical fruits like bananas and pineapples for quite some time now. He buys these fruits in bulk from wholesalers and sells them individually for profits. On average, he earns approximately 11,000 PHP of net income per month.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP ($325). He plans to use the loan proceeds to purchase more fresh fruits to replenish his current inventory. Allan expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business in this fashion.

It is his fervent prayer to live a life of abundance and good health together with his entire family. As a CCT community partner, he faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting, where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he reads. All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is comprised of 15 to 30 community partners, all of whom gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To increase his inventory by purchasing additional fresh fruits

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion G. is a 50-year-old, married woman from the village of Brgy. Lurad, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. Salvacion and her husband have five school-age children. To earn a living, Salvacion owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. Specifically, she runs a general store, where her primary source of income is derived from selling both food and everyday products in her local community. Salvacion has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2011, Salvacion joined ASKI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she hopes to be better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Salvacion is requesting a loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, including sugar, canned goods, and soft drinks. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Salvacion from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To increase her inventory by purchasing additional products such as sugar, canned goods, and soft drinks

loans.name: Evangeline

To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, selling canned goods, breads, snack foods, shampoo, soap & instant noodles in the local community. She also sells vegetables like broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage & celery. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Avelino

texts.en:
Avelino is a hard-working father and husband. He does his best to make his wife and daughter happy.

Avelino is a farmer working in Santo Niño, South Cotabato. He grows rice to sell. He earns about 5,000 PHP per month from this farming. He also raises cows. Avelino wants to improve his earnings.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Minonkpo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe MINONKPO est formé de quatre personnes qui sont tous de la même famille. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Elisabeth, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. 
Elisabeth est mariée à un certain Dieu Donné. Le couple a deux enfants à charge, dont un représente leur propre enfant. Elisabeth habite à Agbodjèdo, un quartier de Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin) avec ses enfants et son mari depuis huit ans. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Il y a près de dix ans  que Elisabeth mène comme activité la vente  de sachets à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Parallèlement à cette activité, Elisabeth vend du maïs. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Elisabeth désire obtenir un autre financement, ensemble avec ses autres membres.
texts.en:
The MINONKPO group consists of four people from the same family. The representative of this group, named Elisabeth, appears in the photo with her hand raised. This is the group’s first time seeking financial support from ALIDé to bolster their activities.

Elisabeth is married to Dieudonné. They have two dependent children, one of whom is their own child. Elisabeth and her family have been living in Agbodjèdo, a district of Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin), for eight years. The couple handle together the various family responsibilities. 

Elisabeth has been selling packaging bags for nearly ten years in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She also sells corn. In order to strengthen her business and better meet customer demand, Elisabeth wishes to obtain further financing together with the other group members.

loans.use: to buy packaging bags and corn

To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling canned goods, noodles, soy sauce & food seasonings in the local community. loans.name: Placidie

texts.en:
Placidie is 47 years old.  She has 5 children who are between the ages of 14 and 25 years old.  They are all in school. Placidie’s husband is a soldier. 

She sells a fabric, called Ibitenge, sun flower oil and small fish. She has done this business for 6 years, and her business has helped her meet her family needs. She is requesting a loan to buy more Ibitenge (traditional fabric) and food items, such as different kinds of flour and small fish.

loans.use: to buy traditional fabric and food stuffs.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Meeting life’s challenges head on is a habit that could be developed only by the brave. Erlinda C., 66, does just that. Erlinda is only an elementary school graduate but right now she manages her own micro business as she learns entrepreneurship as a community partner in CCT*. She is a widow, and takes care of her four children, who are all working.

Erlinda runs her own sari-sari (variety) store, located in the extension of their house. Everyday she observes the buying patterns of her customers and notes down their preferences in terms of the type of item they buy, the price, and the brand. She sees to it that her customers get what they deserve. Monthly, Erlinda earns Php11,000 on average.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan.  She intends to meet the demands of her customers.  As needed, she will buy more stocks of rice, soft drinks, and other grocery items. 

Erlinda acknowledges that no challenges are too hard to deal with.  She knows that the Lord will enable her to overcome, and  will uphold the future of both her children and her business. She dreams of making her sari-sari store grow.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she reads.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en: Mr. Batbayar is 30 years old. He lives with his wife and two children, ages 12 and 1, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife looks after the baby at the moment. Until 2008, Batbayar worked in a textile factory, but he left due to job cuts. Since then, he has been running a taxi business using the family car, and it is his family's only source of income. Since the birth of their second child, the family’s finances have become tight. Batbayar's wife used to run a clothing retail business before the birth, and now she is planning to restore her business. Luckily, Batbayar’s parents have agreed to look after the baby during the day. Mr. Batbayar is asking for a loan to buy the clothes necessary to reopen his wife’s clothes-selling business.

loans.use: to build up a stock of clothing in order to restore his wife’s clothes-selling business

Emilda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP with which she will purchase fertilizer for her farm. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Emilda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

businesses. He is focusing on expanding the dairy business significantly.

Maurice notes that poor state of the roads is a hindrance to business, especially his dairy business, since it results in wastage.

loans.name: Wilhelmina

texts.en:
Meeting life’s challenges head on is a habit that could be developed only by the brave. Wilhelmina E., 49, does just that. Wilhelmina is only a high school graduate but right now she manages her own micro business as she learns entrepreneurship as a community partner in CCT*. She is married to a driver, Jaime, and mothers her three children who are still studying now. Together, they live in Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezno City, Philippines.

Wilhelmina runs her own sari-sari (variety) store located in the extension of their house. Everyday she observes the buying patterns of her customers and notes down their preferences in terms of the type of item they buy, the price, and the brand. She sees to it that her customers get what they deserve. Monthly, Wilhelmina earns Php11,000 on average.

To help her continue operation of her business she is requesting a 8,000 PHP loan. She intends to meet the demands of her customers. As needed, she will buy more stocks of rice, soft drinks, and other grocery items. 

Wilhelmina acknowledges that no challenges are too hard to deal with. She knows that the Lord will enable her to overcome and uphold the future of both her children and her business. She dreams of making her sari-sari store to grow. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she reads.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah N. W. is a young man of twenty two years and is married. He lives in the Kamukuji area in Eldoret town. He runs a motorcycle transport business in Eldoret and has been in this business for two years now. His monthly income is five thousand shillings.

This will be Elijah's first loan from KADET LTD, he plans to use the loan to buy a new motorcycle to make his transportation business reliable.

With the income that he will get he wants to diversify his business and open a retail shop so that he can increase his income. In future he wants to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Patrick Mwaura

texts.en:
Patrick has practised farming in the town of Ndunyu Njeru for the last 15 years. He is 35 years old, married to Priscilla Wanjiru.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be his second loan. He repaid his previous loan of Kshs 15,000 and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy seed and fertilizer.

In future, Patrick hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a hardworking mother of 4 children. She has 4 children who are between the ages of 2 and 19 years old. Rose used to sell a few food stuffs in a basket from place to place but due to the loans she receives form her MFI she now has a permanent place. She sells a variety of food stuffs including green bananas, sweet potatoes etc. From that business she bought a cow and a small house .She is requesting a loan to purchase more food stuffs and make more profits. She plans to save all her profits until she can build a family house.

loans.use: to buy more food stuffs for sale

loans.name: Kahor

texts.en:
H. Kahor is a hardworking man. He is married and has three children. His wife works as a nurse. He works as an accountant at a company called "Habib." Besides this, he is engaged in animal husbandry. With the profit from his cattle sales he was able to arrange the marriage of his child. Kahor would like to get a loan of 6000 Somoni to purchase cattle, as he wishes to increase the number of cattle he owns. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: As everyone knows, fish is a vital fresh food for everybody, in particular families who depend on catching and selling fish from Tunle Sap River, which is the best place for fish sheltering. Svay P., one of these people, currently depends on selling fish at the busy local market. She sells fish that she either gets from her husband’s fishing or buys from her wholesale supplier. Svay P. is a mother blessed with three school-aged children. Svay P. has requested a loan to purchase a second motorcycle for picking up her fish to sell because her old motorcycle has broken down. With the rest of her loan, she will plant potatoes.

loans.use: to purchase a second motorcycle for picking up fish to sell.

loans.name: Kikoni Ii Twimukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en: M. Ephraim is a farmer and a cattle keeper from Kikoni II. He is 33 years old and married with 2 children. He sells milk, beans, maize and so on mostly to his community. He is able to generate UGX 50,000/= weekly but this changes when he sells cattle. He has been in business for 10 years as he has been a farmer all his life. It is hard work that has enabled him to grow. His dream is to be able to grow and become a big farmer in the area as well as educate his children. He needs a loan to be able to improve his plantations by applying mulches and fertilizers.

loans.name: Yousef

texts.ar: يوسف عمره 34 سنة متزوج وله ولدان يعمل في الزراعة ونقل المزروعات له في عمله 5 سنوات يحب عمله ويجيد فيه المتعة في الاستفادة فهو محب للعمل مكب عليه بشكل مميز يريد من خلال عمله ان يؤمن الخضروات والزراعة الجيدة لأهل قريته يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء اسمدة وبزور وصيانة البيك اب في نقل الخضار والفواكه له خبرة كبيرة في هذا المجال يحلم في تطوير مشروعه حتى يتمكن من تحقيق التقدم المادي والاجتماعي له ولعائلته
texts.en: Yousef is 34 years old and married with two children. He works by farming and by transporting the goods he produces on his farm to his customers. He has five years of experience in his work. He likes his work and does it well, as he takes pleasure in doing things which are beneficiA.. He likes to work and is dedicated to his work to an extent which distinguishes him from others in his field. Through his work, he would like to provide the people of his town with high-quality vegetables and farm products. With a loan from A.-Majmoua, he would like to buy fertilizer and seeds, as well as have maintenance done on his pick-up truck, which he uses to transport his fruits and vegetables. He has a lot of experience in his field. His dream is to develop his business so that he can improve his and his family's life economically and socially.

loans.use: buy seeds and fertilizer for his farm, as well as have maintenance done on his pick-up truck, which he uses to transport his farm produce.

loans.name: Mehrab

texts.en:
Mehrab B. was born in 1987. He lives in Lchashen village, area of Sevan, with his grandfather, his father and his sister. Members of Mehrab’s family have been engaged in farming for a long time.   

On his farm, Mehrab raises cows, sheep, a horse, ducks and chickens. With his business profit Mehrab keeps his family and also he was able to buy a truck, which he uses for his farm’s needs.

Mehrab needs a 700,000 AMD loan to buy a cow and some calves for his farm. Cattle enlarging will allow Mehrab to increase his family’s income in the future.

loans.use: To buy a cow and some calves for his farm

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda A. lives in the village of Tuod, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 53 years old, married and has three grown children. She makes a living by buying and selling used clothing (or ukay-ukay) to people in her community. She has been in this line of work for more than five years and makes about 5,500 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has succeeded in repaying her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, from HSPFI and is applying for a new one in the same amount to buy more used clothing to sell to her customers. Her goal is to continue expanding her business.

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
Mrs. Dulamsuren is a 46-year-old widow who lives with her four children in Kherlen city in Dornod Aimag, far eastern Mongolia. Until 1997, she worked for the local city council, then decided to go into business running a meat shop. She has been in this business long enough now to have established suppliers and customers, and some of her children also help her. Unfortunately, one of her children was hit by a car a few years ago and is now blind.  

Dulamsuren is a very determined and hard-working woman -- last year, for example, she personally erected the frame for a new home for her family. She still has much work ahead of her before it will be a comfortable place to live in during the harsh Mongolian winter. She is planning to put foam insulation in the floor, walls and roof and complete the house before summer. She has applied for this loan to buy the materials she needs to finish work on her house.

loans.use: to buy materials to finish building a home for her family.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen C. is 22 years old, married, and has two children.  Her husband is a school teacher.  She buys and sells dry maize in Ndurio trading centre in Kapsabet and has been in this business for three years earning a monthly income of 9,700 KES.

Hellen is requesting a loan for 15,000 KES from KADET LTD, which she will use to purchase seven bags of dry maize and for transport costs. She will use the profits to purchase a posho mill.  Her dream is to own a hotel in Kapsabet town.

loans.use: to purchase dry maize

loans.name: Alisher

texts.en:
Alisher is 34 years old. He is married and has two children. For more than 6 years Alisher has been selling construction materials. He has regular clients and suppliers. Alisher's business is quite profitable and generates a stable income, allowing him to support his family and improve their living conditions. 

He purchases goods from the market of Sultoni Kabir in Dushanbe city. Now he needs to purchase construction materials for his store. For this purpose he requests 5000 Somoni. Alisher promises to repay his loan on time and thanks everyone for their support.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 49 years old and the single mother of three children who are 26, 22 and 13 years old.  She makes a living by running a clothing store which is located in the Komaan Trading Centre in the town of Kapsabet. She has been in this line of work for three years and earns KES.15,000 a month. She has successfully repaid her first loan and is applying for a new one to buy more clothing to sell in her store. She will use the additional income made possible by this loan to educate her children and improve her family's living standards. She also hopes to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Meeting life’s challenges head on is a habit that could be developed only by the brave. Judith C., 41, does just like that. She is married to Reynaldo, a technician, and they have been blessed with two children who are studying in public elementary and high schools nearby.  Judith works very hard to help her husband earn a living so that they will be able to send their children all the way through college. The family lives in Brgy. Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines.

Judith is a distributor of food supplements and other natural medicines such as CMD or Concentrated Mineral Drops.  She has been in this business for quite some time now. She buys these items at discounted prices and sells them at regular prices to her customers. Judith has already built up a clientele through her friends, relatives and other social connections. She earns an estimated monthly net income of around 11,000 PHP. To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan, which she intends to use to purchase more cases and boxes of natural medicines ordered in advance by her customers.  

Judith acknowledges that no challenge is too hard to deal with. She knows that the Lord will enable her to overcome and uphold the future of both her children and her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she reads. 

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for cases of natural medicines ordered in advance by her customers.

Janet has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Janet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. Janet is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables such as eggplants and squash. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Janet from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
